alert.note: Alert for Wheeler (Oregon) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Pendleton (Northeast Oregon and Southeast Washington)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 06 at 5:05AM PDT until May 10 at 7:10AM PDT by NWS Pendleton
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Oregon... John Day River at Service Creek affecting Wheeler County. For the John Day River...including Service Creek...Moderate flooding is forecast. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/pdt. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL WEDNESDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...John Day River at Service Creek. * WHEN...Until Wednesday morning. * IMPACTS...At 11.5 feet, * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:30 AM PDT Saturday the stage was 11.9 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 4:30 AM PDT Saturday was 12.1 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise to 12.6 feet late this afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage early Monday afternoon to 10.9 feet late Tuesday morning. It will rise above flood stage early Wednesday morning to 11.7 feet Wednesday afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage again early Thursday morning to 9.6 feet Sunday, May 14. It will then rise again but remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 11.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 12.9 feet on 03/14/1983. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Fld Observed Forecasts (5 am PDT) Location Stg Stg Day/Time Sun Mon Tue John Day River Service Creek 11.5 11.9 Sat 4 am PDT 12.3 11.8 10.9 &&
info.instruction: Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles.
